image.altText: A funeral that shows a tribute and people standing with their head downs

props.synopsis: The son of South Australia's police commissioner has been remembered as a "force of nature" in a touching memorial service, as more than $45,000 is raised for a youth foundation in his honour.

title.children: 'We will love you forever, Charlie boy': SA police commissioner's son farewelled at public twilight service

image.altText: Bare branches covering a large beige building in the background

props.synopsis: The 16-year-old South Australian boy has been sentenced as an adult to three years in prison, but is now eligible to apply for parole after his time served in youth detention was taken into account.

title.children: Schoolboy sentenced over terrorism offences including possessing 'graphic and disturbing videos'

image.altText: Three soldiers, two male, one female, walk near military vehicles and a flying Istael flag

props.synopsis: The 7am local time deadline for the Israel-Hamas ceasefire has now passed with no deal being reached for the hostage and prisoner exchange to continue.

title.children: Israel's military says it has resumed fighting, accusing Hamas of violating truce moments after deadline passes

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Analysis: The ceasefire is over, so what now?
Israel military resume combat, accuse Hamas of violating truce

image.altText: A man playing the piano and singing onstage

props.synopsis: Adelaide 36ers star Isaac Humphries made international headlines last year when he announced publicly that he is gay, becoming the first NBL player to do so. Now he's preparing to reveal another side of himself – his singing talents – on stage at the biggest arts festival in the southern hemisphere.

title.children: 'I've hidden a lot of my life for so long': Basketball star to reveal new side of himself on major festival stage

image.altText: A man looking over the back of a cinema seat with a cinema screen behind him

props.synopsis: While hit films like Barbie have helped bring people back to their local cinemas post-pandemic, managers say that momentum has been lost as movie production has slowed.

title.children: Despite blockbuster successes, regional cinemas are still waiting for their COVID comeback

image.altText: A four-wheel drive goes through dunes at Stockton beach - two other four-wheel drives are behind the car.

props.synopsis: Wildlife groups in SA have found some unlikely allies in their lobbying for better protection of bird habitat, with 4WD clubs supporting the need for seasonal restrictions.

title.children: South Australia 'behind other states' when it comes to beach protection

image.altText: A woman with glasses looking serious in front of a yellow wall

props.synopsis: Almost two dozen South Australian teenagers in state care who are at risk of sexual exploitation and abuse have been unable to get the help they need from a specialist public health service that has reached capacity, according to the state's child protection watchdog

title.children: At-risk South Australian children in care miss out on specialist support, child protection watchdog warns

image.altText: Paul Singer, founder of Elliott Management

props.synopsis: Elliott Management is little-known outside the world of high finance, but throughout its legendary history it's made many enemies, including the Argentine navy. It's now eyeing a stoush with an Australian state over energy.

title.children: Why one of the most feared investors in the world holds the key to an Australian energy crisis

image.altText: A group of people holding umbrellas

props.synopsis: A magistrate says the deaths of five teenagers in a crash in south-west Sydney last year were "completely avoidable" after jailing driver Tyrell Edwards for 12 years.

title.children: Gasps in court as Buxton P-plate driver jailed for 12 years over crash that killed five teenagers

image.altText: A mid-shot of two Indigenous women standing outdoors in a country town, with one of them wiping away tears.

props.synopsis: After a morning of confusion and anguish, Cleveland Dodd's funeral will go ahead later today, with WA authorities reversing an eleventh-hour decision to block his incarcerated father from attending.

title.children: 'It hurts a lot': Cleveland Dodd's funeral to go ahead as move to stop father attending reversed

image.altText: Brittany Higgins outside court with an inset image of her going through Parliament House security.

props.synopsis: Brittany Higgins tells the Federal Court she tried to "reclaim" the dress she alleges she was sexually assaulted in by wearing it at a Liberal Party function in the months afterwards.

title.children: Brittany Higgins re-wore dress she was allegedly raped in to 'reclaim' it, court hears

image.altText: Sunset over a bend in the majestic Murray River at Murtho, with red tall cliffs

props.synopsis: First Nations water groups have welcomed changes to the Murray-Darling Basin Plan which will formally acknowledge their connection to water and aim to increase Indigenous ownership.

title.children: Murray-Darling Basin Plan changes recognise a First Nations connection to water in 'small step forward'

image.altText: Cattle in pens at a saleyard.

props.synopsis: Prices for some cattle have doubled as buyer confidence is restored following rainfall for many areas that have endured a long dry spell.

title.children: Farmers breathe sigh of relief as livestock prices rebound after rain

image.altText: Two people holding hands in a hospital.

props.synopsis: State leaders are calling for the federal government to amend Commonwealth laws and allow telehealth consultations for patients seeking access to voluntary assisted dying services, in the wake of a Federal Court ruling.

title.children: Calls to ensure voluntary assisted dying access for rural and regional Australians

image.altText: A close up photo of the front of a Tesla Cybertruck in a showroom, with some people standing behind it

props.synopsis: Experts say Elon Musk's electric car company is not living up to some of its promises as it delivers its first all-new model in nearly four years.

title.children: Tesla begins deliveries of long-delayed Cybertruck, with higher prices and lower range than first announced

props.synopsis: An AI-based analysis of 20 years of logging by VicForests, shared exclusively with the ABC, shows for the first time the potential scale of failed regeneration in Victoria's state forests.

title.children: 'It's basically dead': The legacy of decades of logging

image.altText: The outside of the County Court of Victoria building.

props.synopsis: In 1984, Robert Barry chased down a 24-year-old woman and raped her in a "degrading" attack. Nearly four decades on, he has been sentenced in a Victorian court.

title.children: Forty-year-old rape case solved through 'Cold Case Freezer Project'

image.altText: A map showing congested areas in and around the Rozelle Interchange

props.synopsis: The much-discussed Rozelle Interface has proved to have teething problems after opening on Sunday. But experts say it isn't user error.

title.children: Sydney's multi-billion-dollar roadway with choke points designers didn't see coming

image.altText: A graphic showing a confused person looking at different plastics.

props.synopsis: Does a product wrapped in earthy beige make you feel it must be environmentally responsible? New research shows how easy it is for marketers to imply their products are "sustainable" without necessarily backing it up.

title.children: These are the tricks advertisers use to fake sustainable products

image.altText: Shoebridge gestures with a hand as he speaks inside the mural hall.

props.synopsis: Amid the continuing conflict in Gaza, Greens spokesman for Defence and Veterans' Affairs David Shoebridge says the government is selling "weapons, after weapons, after weapons" to Israel. RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked David Shoebridge on Australia selling weapons to Israel. Here's what we found

image.altText: Peter Dutton smile

props.synopsis: If the government's position doesn't improve substantially, people will take a more serious look at Peter Dutton — the hard man from Queensland — and speculate about what sort of prime minister he'd make, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: What would happen if Dutton managed to win the election? What kind of prime minister would he make?

image.altText: A house with a red roof underwater

props.synopsis: Less than $900,000 out of $12m has been handed out to victims of the Fitzroy River flood disaster in January. Just 24 people have received money.

title.children: Millions of dollars in Kimberley flood donations still locked up, 11 months on from the disaster

image.altText: An actress standing in the middle of a dirt road with long hair and a dirty face

props.synopsis: George Miller's dystopian franchise Mad Max is back with the iconic Australian director behind the lens and Chris Hemsworth and Anya Taylor-Joy co-starring.

title.children: The first trailer for Mad Max prequel Furiosa — starring Chris Hemsworth and Anya Taylor-Joy — has dropped

image.altText: A still from a Crock Of Gold shows a bearded Shane MacGowan in 2019

props.synopsis: Why your favourite songwriter is mourning the loss of Shane MacGowan, who died this week at 65.

title.children: Shane MacGowan wrote powerful, poignant songs. One of them became an intense and superb Christmas anthem

image.altText: An aerial view of a property including greenhouses

props.synopsis: Victorian Special Operations Group police have launched a series of aerial raids in central Victoria, arresting foreign nationals and setting more than 1.4 tonnes of cannabis ablaze.

title.children: Police drop from the sky to destroy $11m in cannabis operations on remote properties

image.altText: Sold sign on Queenslander-style house in a street in Brisbane.

props.synopsis: Property prices are still growing strongly in Brisbane, Perth and Adelaide, but CoreLogic's figures show a slowdown in Sydney and falls for Melbourne and Hobart.

title.children: House prices are 'rocketing along' in a few cities, but starting to fall in others

image.altText: A side profile of a young boy with glasses with a long red mullet, which is blowing in the wind.

props.synopsis: Queenslander Jayce Bowers, 12, has already won a state title for his meticulously cultivated mane. This weekend he will see how his glorious 'do fares against the very best in the nation and beyond at Mulletfest.

title.children: 12-year-old Queenslander set to go mullet-to-mullet with world's best

image.altText: A small town street looking empty with a long empty road

props.synopsis: A Senate inquiry examining the closure of bank branches in regional Australia has grilled the competition watchdog and financial regulator in Canberra, while the ASX finished lower after a modest day of trade.

title.children: Regulators grilled over regional bank closures, falling inflation in US and Europe suggests end of rate rises, ASX slips — as it happened

image.altText: A person with pink hair and a colourful skirt in their apartment on a cloudy day

props.synopsis: There are over 200,000 Australians with an autism spectrum condition. But lack of healthcare training and understanding is leaving many of them without quality care.

title.children: Misdiagnosed and gaslit: When autistic Australians go to the doctor, it's often a 'traumatic' experience

image.altText: Mitzi Jonelle Tan, of the Philippines, center, participates in a Fridays for Future protest.

props.synopsis: Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber, the president of the COP28 climate conference in Dubai, says his country, the United Arab Emirates, will chip in $US100 million, a sum matched by Germany. But critics say much more is needed.

title.children: COP28 nations begin climate fund, but experts say it's a paltry sum

image.altText: Alaa and his son at the site of their home which has now been reduced to rubble.

props.synopsis: Getting a visitor visa to come to Australia is one thing, getting out of Gaza is another matter entirely. We speak to people inside Gaza who have the visa about the huge challenges they face getting to the Rafa crossing and their relatives here in Australia who are worried sick if they’ll make it alive.

title.children: Checkpoints, bribes and seven hours on foot. Here's what it takes to leave Gaza

image.altText: Gurpatwant Singh Pannun, pictured in front of a dark wooded background, looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: Until a reporter called him last week, Gurpatwant Singh Pannun says he knew nothing about an alleged plot to have him killed. But he says he wasn't shocked to hear he was a target.

title.children: 'I'm ready to face death': Alleged kill plot against New York lawyer tests India-US relations

image.altText: Five men in defense uniforms stand on a platform.

props.synopsis: New research reveals the ranks of senior officers in the Australian military has almost doubled over the past twenty years, despite a steady decline in overall numbers.

title.children: Growing number of senior officers in 'top-heavy' Australian Defence Force

image.altText: Hands move over a scrabble board covered in tiles

props.synopsis: The board game almost hit the shelves 75 years ago without a board and under a very different moniker: Criss-Crosswords.

title.children: The longest Scrabble word gets you 1,778 points — Australian players say the game gives them much more important things
